summary: Service trailer brakes light pops up and chimes over and over again. I've never pulled a trailer. It's distracting and will randomly go off. Seems to go off when gas is below 1/4 tank. Sometimes it goes months without happening. Sometimes it happens a few days in a row.  The dealership says they can't do anything unless they see it go off.

One week it's almost every day, one week it seems fine.  The dealership said they have heard this a lot and laughed when they told me the manufacturer has told them it's normal. It's definitely not normal.

The contact owns a 2017 GMC Sierra 1500. The contact stated while driving 70 MPH, the vehicle began to independently brake without depressing the brake pedal. The contact stated that the "trailer brake service" and the "service brake" warning light were illuminated. The contact pulled off the road safely and drove the vehicle to his residence. The contact had not taken the vehicle to a local dealer. The vehicle was not diagnosed or repaired. The contact had received an unknown recall letter from the manufacturer. The manufacturer had not been informed of the failure. The failure mileage was approximately 14,230. The VIN was unavailable.

The contact owns a 2017 GMC Sierra Denali. The contact was notified by her state inspection office that her vehicle was included in NHTSA Campaign Number: 21V496000 (Equipment). The dealer was notified about the recall and informed her that parts for the recall repair were not yet available. The manufacturer had been notified of the recall and contacted several dealers in her area; however, the dealers also did not have part available for the recall. The contact stated that the manufacturer had exceeded a reasonable amount of time for the repair. The contact had not experienced a failure. Parts distribution disconnect.

The rear window defrost hasn't been working since I've owned the truck. Doing some research on it.....there's lots of complaints online with issues involving this problem.  Some fires also. I did find that there were 160,000 or so recalled in Canada. Same issues. Mostly involving being remote started. Which is what happened to mine. I remote started mine....walked about 50 yards to the truck...heard a loud pop.....the rear window exploded ! Glass went everywhere  !! It's definitely a safety issue....especially if someone had been in the rear seat !! I've ran the Vin # and checked with the closest dealer but they weren't any help. It's hard to figure there were so many issues in Canada....but none here. The replacement glasses are made in Canada, about every complaint I read involved remote start during cold weather.....which the rear window defrost come on if the temps below a certain level. Lots of owners were disabling the defrost on the rear window by removing the fuse and or relay.

I have had ongoing issues with my 2017 GMC Sierra Denali Truck's performance since it was purchased in May of 2017 of which I have all the service records to show. In mid-June 2021, the check engine light appeared on the dashboard and I immediately contacted the service department at the GMC dealership in Fremont to schedule an appointment. On 6/18, I dropped the vehicle off for the scheduled appointment. After picking the vehicle up, I immediately noticed that it was shuddering and vibrating upon acceleration of 30-40, 40-50, 50-60 & 75-85 miles per hour. The issue persisted and I returned the vehicle to the dealership on 7/1. After several attempts during the month of July 2021 by the dealership to fix the issue and it not being resolved, I finally contacted GMC Corporate to discuss the problems and options. I was assigned a case number and to customer service assistant Farris.  Unfortunately, GMC customer assistance was not very helpful with my claim and was not responsive. At one point, I asked to be referred to a supervisor but was never given that opportunity. Finally, on 8/26, I was advised that based on GMC's evaluation and review of my case, the vehicle would not be replaced or repurchased based on the history of the vehicle repairs. He did not explain to me in detail the basis of this decision. He stated that my options were to take the vehicle back to the Fremont dealership or take it to another a dealership (where I may be charged). I decided to take the vehicle to another dealership which was GMC, Modesto. The appointment was scheduled on 9/14 and the vehicle was returned to me on 9/15 after they could not diagnose or repair the vehicle. The service adviser explained that I would have to return to the dealership in Fremont. On 9/17, the vehicle was towed to that dealership. On 9/23 at 4:55 pm, service manager Dave called stating "two fuel injectors they put in previously were replaced again and wanted permission for the shop foreman to drive it home."

Within a couple of days after purchasing the vehicle new I noticed a vibration or shudder when the transmission shifted. Also, the truck would slam into gear almost like being hit in the back end, and on a few occasions while driving on the highway the truck would just downshift by itself thereby causing the engine RPM's to rev above 5,000. It has been to the dealer four times, transmission has been re-calibrated, the new and improved fluid flush and these problems still exist. The truck has just under 60K miles and has started downshifting on a regular basis causing the engine to rev. How long is that going to last before the engine blows or causes permanent damage?

GM has known issues, which I'm sure the NHTSA is aware of.  This involves transmission in 2015-2019 model trucks, both GMC and Chevrolet, among other GM vehicles.  In my research there have been no less than 13 TSB's issues by GM trying to rectify these issues.  The latest TSB states that a new blend of transmission fluid is the fix.  In my instance the transmission started shifting hard with less than 30K miles.  Took to dealership and they reprogrammed the transmission control module.  Fixed the issue for a while but then started back after about 10K miles.  In Feb. 2020 with 60K miles a transmission temperature sensor failed on the transmission.  I took it in to replace sensor and as a result they had to change the fluid at which time they told me they replaced it with the new recommended fluid.  Now at 94K miles it has started producing the hard shuddering at certain speeds.  This is the main problem the fluid change is supposed to fix.  Well guess what.  It does fix it.  I'm now scheduled to take it back in on Monday 8-9-21 to have the torque converter replaced.  The company I work for has about 12 of these model GMC trucks and 7 of them have had to go back in to fix this same issue.  Some of them multiple times.  I'm out of warranty and these repairs are not cheap.  The biggest safety issue is the tranny could fail at any point going down the road and leave me with no drivetrain and potentially get hit.  In my 40 years of driving and owning 20 vehicles between me, my wife and 3 kids I have never had a tranny fail.  This is the first and GM has know about this issue for years.  They need to be made to fix these issues and replace all transmission that are having issues and repay me the money I've already paid and the money I'll have to pay next week.  This is ridiculous that NHTSA has not gotten involved enough to force GM to correct this.  You need to force the hand of GM to make this right.   You know of the problems, now get it fixed!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

A GMC DEALERSHIP HAS ADMITTED THERE IS AN ISSUE AND RECOMMENDS REPLACING THE VACUUM PUMP BUT HAS BEEN UNABLE TO SOURCE THE PARTS IN OVER TWO WEEKS AND HAS NO ETA FOR WHEN THE PART WILL BE AVAILABLE. THE SECOND OCCURRENCE INVOLVED BACKING INTO MY DRIVEWAY AND NEARLY CAUSING A COLLISION BECAUSE OF POOR BRAKING PERFORMANCE.  NOW THAT I FULLY AWARE OF THE ISSUE, THE VEHICLE IS DRIVEN SPARINGLY (ONLY WHEN ABSOLUTELY NEEDED) AND WITH GREAT CARE.  THE CHARACTERIZATION OF THIS ISSUE BY GM AS NOT BEING A GRAVE SAFETY CONCERN IS INACCURATE.  THEIR INABILITY TO SOURCE PARTS IN A TIMELY MANNER IS INEXCUSABLE.
